author: By Matthew Rosenberg and Maria Abi-Habib
title: As Gazans Scrounge for Food and Water, Hamas Sits on a Rich Trove of Supplies
description: Hamas has spent years stockpiling desperately needed fuel, food and medicine, as well as ammo and weapons, in the miles of tunnels it has carved out under Gaza.
content: As supplies of virtually every basic human necessity dwindle in Gaza, one group in the besieged enclave remains well-stocked: Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: After 64 Years of Family Gatherings, a Second Chance
description: Joseph Potenzano and Mary Elkind first met at a wedding in 1959, but it would be decades before they rekindled their short-lived romance (karaoke helped).
content: When Joseph John Potenzano, 93, and Mary Johanna Elkind, 84, announced their engagement in July, both of their families had questions. While a decision to wed at their age raised some eyebrows, a larger concern was how — and where — they had met.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Chinese Jet Flies Within 10 Feet of U.S. Bomber, Pentagon Says
description: The fighter jet neared a B-52 during a maneuver over the South China Sea on Tuesday night, the U.S. military said. China had no immediate response.
content: A Chinese fighter jet came within 10 feet of a U.S. Air Force B-52 bomber over the South China Sea this week in a nighttime maneuver that nearly caused a collision, the United States military said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: At Barcelona, Timing Is Everything
description: The Barcelona team that faces Real Madrid in Saturday’s Clásico will be marked by youth, mostly because the club’s dire straits meant it had to be.
content: As he rose through the ranks at Barcelona, Gerard Deulofeu seemed to have everything. Above all, he was fast, possessed of that urgent, quicksilver sort of speed that carries with it an air of permanent menace. But he had composure, too, a coolness on the ball, that stood out even at La Masia, Barcelona’s revered academy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: How a Dentist Protects Her Family’s Teeth on Halloween
description: A dentist shares five tricks for managing treats.
content: Dr. Apoena Ribeiro is a pediatric dentist and microbiologist at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. She’s also a parent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Marie Elizabeth Oliver
title: Washington Was Stunned by the New Speaker’s Rise. So Was His District.
description: Many in Mike Johnson’s northern Louisiana district hope his surprise elevation will bring attention to their region, which they feel has been overlooked.
content: When Chip Hemphill is on a hunting trip with his friends, looking for white-tailed deer and hogs, he doesn’t typically find himself discussing who is second in line to the presidency. His wife, Kathleen, barely mentions politics while overseeing archery lessons at Hoot & Holler Archery, their store in Bossier City in northern Louisiana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: A Developing Situation in Gaza
description: The latest from the Israel-Hamas war. Weekday afternoons with Times journalists on the ground.
content: Amid an apparent digital blackout in Gaza and an announcement by the Israeli military that it is expanding operations there, Patrick Kingsley, The New York Times’s Jerusalem bureau chief, joins Matina Stevis-Gridneff, the Brussels bureau chief, with the latest on Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: A Plan to Defeat Hamas and Avoid a Bloodbath
description: A former Israeli prime minister sketches a plausible path to victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: TransUnion Failed to Quickly Place or Remove Freezes on Credit Reports
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau accused the credit bureau, one of three major credit reporting agencies, of “lying to consumers.”
content: Freezing your credit report has long been regarded as one of the best steps to take to make sure identity thieves cannot obtain loans or credit cards in your name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Magic Mushroom Therapy Is Met With a Mix of Elation and Trepidation
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 27, 2023.
content: “I wouldn’t say it’s a ‘one and done, I’m completely cured.’ It takes work.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Anjali Huynh
title: Democrats Splinter Over Israel as the Young, Diverse Left Rages at Biden
description: As a raw divide over the war ripples through liberal America, a coalition of young voters and people of color is breaking with the president, raising new questions about his strength entering 2024.
content: The Democratic Party’s yearslong unity behind President Biden is beginning to erode over his steadfast support of Israel in its escalating war with the Palestinians, with a left-leaning coalition of young voters and people of color showing more discontent toward him than at any point since he was elected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: Cornel West’s Improvisational Run for President: ‘It’s Jazz All the Way Down’
description: Is the celebrity professor’s candidacy a wild variable in the 2024 presidential campaign or performance art? Yes, he says.
content: Cornel West, the left-wing public intellectual and independent presidential candidate, stood on a rainy stretch of suburban highway in New York’s Rockland County. “Watch that truck!” he called out, holding up a United Auto Workers sign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marjorie Ingall
title: An Embarrassment of Witches
description: Jewish magic, Southern conjure magic and Scottish magic abound in new middle grade novels by Laurel Snyder, Eden Royce and Elle McNicoll.
content: Girls have always been fascinated by witchcraft, with its challenge to patriarchal norms, its feminine deities and spirits, its reclamation of otherness. Today, though, the lure seems stronger than ever. Magic answers a yearning for creativity and ritual in an increasingly controlling, conformist world. And at a time when kids are more and more concerned about the environment, a faith tradition focused on protecting nature can be empowering. (It’s not uncommon at climate-emergency marches to see signs reading, “We are the granddaughters of the witches you couldn’t burn.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Thompson
title: The Most Controversial Statue in America Surrenders to the Furnace
description: Monuments to the Confederacy got emotionally rich ceremonies when they were installed. They deserve no less when they come down.
content: Last Saturday in a small foundry, a man in heat-resistant attire pulled down his gold-plated visor, turned on his plasma torch and sliced into the face of Robert E. Lee. The hollow bronze head glowed green and purple as the flame burned through layers of patina and wax. Drops of molten red metal cascaded to the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Israel Expands Its Operations in Gaza
description: Also, police scour a river for the gunman in Maine. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: The Israeli military launched an intense bombardment of the Gaza Strip this evening and said it was “expanding” its activity there. Cellular and internet service were cut off for much of the territory, and Palestinians said fear and panic were spreading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Ida Applebroog, Whose Art Confronted Relationships, Dies at 93
description: She developed a varied but recognizable style in multiple mediums, characterized by the raw, mordant humor of a woman under no illusions.
content: Ida Applebroog, who confronted the violence, coercion and mortality that simmer beneath everyday relationships with a prolific stream of drawings, paintings, sculptures and videos, died on Oct. 21 at her home in Manhattan. She was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Santos Pleads Not Guilty to New Charges, but House May Yet Expel Him
description: Mr. Santos, Republican of New York, pleaded not guilty on Friday to 10 new federal charges, but could face a House expulsion vote as soon as next week.
content: Five months ago, as he made his first appearance in federal court after his criminal indictment, George Santos, the embattled first-term Republican congressman from New York, was in full George Santos mode — denying wrongdoing, chastising his critics and pledging to prove his innocence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: How Truths Are Told at a Liquor Store in ‘The Holdovers’
description: The director Alexander Payne narrates a sequence from his film, featuring Paul Giamatti and Dominic Sessa.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Five Years After Pittsburgh Synagogue Attack, Recovery Mixes With Fresh Grief
description: The Tree of Life community was “universally embraced” after an antisemitic shooting. But with Israel engaged in war, some now feel alone.
content: It has been five years since a gunman stormed into the Tree of Life synagogue in Pittsburgh, killing 11 worshipers and wounding six others in the deadliest antisemitic attack in American history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum and Dana Rubinstein
title: Security Guard Cleared of Assaulting Top Adviser to Mayor Adams
description: Manhattan prosecutors said that camera footage and numerous witness interviews did not support the allegations made by Timothy Pearson, a top mayoral aide.
content: A security guard at a New York City migrant shelter who was accused by one of Mayor’s Eric Adams’s top advisers of shoving him during a violent altercation was cleared on Friday of criminal wrongdoing when a judge dismissed charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: West End Theatergoers Grumble as Prices for the Best Seats Surge
description: Concern is growing that a night at the theater in London is becoming unaffordable, especially when a production has starry names, like Kenneth Branagh’s “King Lear.”
content: When hundreds of playgoers lined up outside Wyndham’s Theater in London this week, the mood was excited. They had come to see Kenneth Branagh, the revered Shakespearean actor, directing and playing the title role in “King Lear.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. Imposes New Sanctions to Cut Off Hamas Funding
description: The Biden administration also targeted the group’s Iranian supporters.
content: The United States on Friday imposed a new round of sanctions aimed at cutting off financing for Hamas, targeting its investment fund and Iranians who funnel money and support to the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Michael Bragman, 83, Dies; Led a Failed Legislative Coup in New York
description: As the State Assembly’s respected majority leader, he attempted to oust his boss, Sheldon Silver, the body’s imperious speaker. That move ended his career.
content: Michael J. Bragman, a Democratic powerhouse who was deposed as the majority leader of the New York State Assembly and retired from politics after mounting an unsuccessful and politically suicidal coup against the speaker, Sheldon Silver, in 2000, died on Oct. 13 in Syracuse, N.Y. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Airstrikes Contain Twin Messages to Iran, American Officials Say
description: The airstrikes were the latest gamble by the United States to modify Iran’s behavior, few of which have worked in the past.
content: The American strikes on two Iranian military munitions stockpiles in Syria on Friday were carefully designed, President Biden’s aides said, to send two distinct messages to Tehran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Ford
title: Overlooked No More: Adefunmi I, Who Introduced African Americans to Yoruba
description: A pivotal conversation led him on a quest to understand African history and create a one-of-a-kind village for practitioners of the Yoruba religion.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Maggie Astor
title: Dean Phillips Announces Long-Shot Challenge to Biden in Democratic Primary
description: The Minnesota lawmaker is going up against an incumbent president who has significant financial advantages.
content: Representative Dean Phillips, a moderate Minnesota Democrat who has for months publicly argued that President Biden should not run for re-election, announced his candidacy for president on Thursday, setting up an underdog challenge for the Democratic nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Few Americans Have Gotten the New Covid Shots, C.D.C. Finds
description: About 7 percent of adults have rolled up their sleeves for the new vaccines, according to new agency data.
content: Few Americans have received the latest vaccines against the coronavirus: Just over 7 percent of adults and 2 percent of children had received the shot as of Oct. 14, according to a survey presented on Thursday to scientific advisers to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randy Boyagoda
title: ‘The Reformatory’ Turns the Lingering Impact of Racism Into Literal Ghosts
description: In Tananarive Due’s new novel, a boy sentenced to a brutal reform school must capture the phantoms of those who died at the institution in the past.
content: If you’re a committed reader of contemporary fiction, you are probably familiar with this premise: In mid-20th-century Jim Crow America, an unsuspecting young Black man finds himself sent to a fictionalized version of Florida’s infamously brutal Dozier School on dubious, if not false, charges. While there, he must do what he can to survive, which is far from a sure thing given the open secret of nighttime abuse, unexplained disappearances and student deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz, Anna Betts, Eduardo Medina and Jenna Russell
title: Portraits of the Dead Emerge From Tragedy in Maine
description: What began as a seemingly ordinary evening in Lewiston turned horrific after a gunman entered a bowling alley and a local bar and began shooting, killing 18 people.
content: Some were bowling, others were playing cornhole, some were enjoying a game of pool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Domenech
title: Welcome, Speaker Johnson, to the Worst Job in Politics
description: He has inherited a dramatic, not to mention unwieldy, series of political challenges for the House itself, as well as for the fortunes of his G.O.P. caucus.
content: Congratulations are due to Representative Mike Johnson of Louisiana, who as the new speaker of the House has inherited the worst job in politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simran Hans
title: A Landmark of Black Cinema, Restored for a New Age
description: The British director Horace Ové struggled to get his 1975 film, “Pressure,” made and released. Now, weeks after his death, a new restoration is celebrated in New York and London.
content: On a recent, rainy evening in London, movie fans gathered at the British Film Institute theater for a much-anticipated premiere, though the film was made nearly 50 years ago: Horace Ové’s newly restored “Pressure,” considered the first feature by a Black British director.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen King
title: Stephen King on Mass Shootings: We’re Out of Things to Say
description: Every mass shooting is a gut-punch; but such things can and will happen anywhere and everywhere in this locked-and-loaded country.
content: There is no solution to the gun problem, and little more to write, because Americans are addicted to firearms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Guerrero and Katie Van Syckle
title: Time Celebrates a Hundred People and the City Toasts Elmhurst’s Frontline Workers
description: Jalen Hurts, Kelsea Ballerini, Julio Torres and more gathered for the “Time100 Next” party, and Elmhurst Hospital celebrated its 190-year history at the American Museum of Natural History.
content: On Tuesday night, at a candlelit event space near Penn Station in Manhattan, Mayor David Holt of Oklahoma City leaned over and introduced himself to Lily Gladstone, a star of Martin Scorsese’s new film, “Killers of the Flower Moon.” Victor J. Glover Jr., the first Black astronaut on the International Space Station for an extended stay, was seated behind him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: What Is a Teddy Roosevelt Presidential Library Doing in North Dakota?
description: The $333 million project rising in a tiny badlands town wants to showcase the 26th president and his visionary environmental record — without ignoring his flaws.
content: Here in Medora, a tiny town in the badlands of western North Dakota, Teddy Roosevelt is everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Vincent Asaro, Mobster Acquitted in Lufthansa Heist, Dies at 86
description: In a stunning verdict, he was found not guilty of participating in the storied 1978 theft, retold in the film “Goodfellas.” Then he went to prison over a road rage incident.
content: Vincent Asaro, a career mobster who was found not guilty of murder and of helping to organize the staggering $6 million Lufthansa heist at John F. Kennedy Airport — one of the biggest cash heists in American history — only to be sentenced to prison when he was 82 over road-rage revenge, died on Sunday in Queens. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Older Americans Are Winning the Economic War of the Generations
description: That might not be great for the long-term financial health of the country.
content: If there is a war of the generations, we older Americans are winning it. As evidence, I present two remarkable charts, which are my versions of charts made by the Center on the Economics and Demography of Aging at the University of California, Berkeley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: As Users Abandon X, Sports Twitter Endures
description: Many users have migrated to other platforms since Elon Musk bought Twitter, but sports fans still find it indispensable.
content: Hours after the Texas Rangers beat the Houston Astros on Monday night to advance to the World Series, Adolis García, the Rangers right fielder, posted 29 shushing-face emojis on X, the social platform once known as Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: obscurity
description: This word has appeared in 146 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word obscurity has appeared in 146 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 26 in “A Mongolian Marathoner’s Secret Weapon? Staying Power” by Scott Cacciola:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: San Francisco Has a New Slogan, and Not Everyone Is a Fan
description: A $4 million ad campaign with the motto “It All Starts Here” aims to repair the city’s battered image.
content: Walking around my San Francisco neighborhood of Glen Park the other afternoon, I saw them everywhere. New signs with the logo “It All Starts Here” hang in most windows — at the corner cafe, the bar, the bakery, the hardware store and the hair salon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By E. Justin Swanson
title: Larry Elder Ends Long-Shot Presidential Bid
description: Mr. Elder, a Los Angeles Republican who bills himself as “the sage from South Central,” endorsed Donald Trump.
content: Larry Elder, a conservative talk radio host from California whose run for the Republican presidential nomination never gained traction, ended his campaign on Thursday and endorsed Donald J. Trump, the front-runner in the crowded field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
title: Li Keqiang, Chinese Premier Eclipsed by Xi Jinping, Dies at 68
description: Mr. Li, who retired in March, was muscled out of the premier’s usual policymaking roles by Mr. Xi. Chinese citizens expressed shock at his death, from a heart attack.
content: Li Keqiang, China’s former premier, who came to power promising to improve the lot of private companies and restrain the reach of the state but was overshadowed by the hard-line top leader, Xi Jinping, died early Friday. He was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Dwyer
title: When a Breakup Is an Act of Love
description: Single again in midlife, I am learning how to embrace reality over fantasy in a new relationship.
content: A prompt on the Hinge dating app asks for two truths and a lie. I could say: I was in a cult as a teenager. I got engaged after only two months of dating. I had a stroke at 44, after ending my 19-year marriage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Witches on the Water
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles and Giovanni Russonello
title: Mr Eazi’s Anthem of Gratitude, and 11 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Silvana Estrada, Old Dominion, Nadine Shah and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis Says He Will ‘Reorient’ U.S. Foreign Policy to Counter China
description: While the G.O.P. field has largely moved away from the neoconservative policies of George W. Bush, Mr. DeSantis has taken heat for some of his isolationist tendencies, including on Ukraine.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, working to maintain his second-place status in the Republican primary, said Friday that as president he would “reorient” U.S. foreign policy to give clear priority to China while downplaying national security risks posed by conflicts such as Russia’s war on Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Trincia
title: It Might Be Time to Consider Timisoara
description: OK, “Little Vienna” might be a stretch, but the Romanian city is a genuine, livable and multicultural place that offers just enough for visitors to fill two or three days.
content: Families stroll and savor gelato cones as bike couriers whiz by. Pensioners relax on benches near manicured flower beds while earbud-wearing hipsters walk dogs and children chase pigeons by a fountain laden with bronze fish. The scene in Victory Square in Timisoara, Romania, is quintessentially European — modern meets Old World.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Ain’t Gonna
description: Adrian Johnson opens our solving weekend.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: A Necessary Learning Curve
description: “It took me far too long to learn this stuff. They understood it so much sooner.”
content: “In the past, the fantasy would have eclipsed the reality,” Annie Dwyer writes in this week’s Modern Love essay. “I would have believed it was love, letting it drag on even if it made me irritable and anxious. I would have wasted hours analyzing what I did wrong and waiting for him to come around. This time, I could see the dead end.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Thornton Wilder’s ‘Our Town’ to Return to Broadway Next Fall
description: A new production, directed by Kenny Leon, will feature a diverse cast and will aim to speak to contemporary America.
content: “Our Town,” one of the most revered and enduring American dramas, will return to Broadway next fall in a new production directed by Kenny Leon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Jack Healy
title: The Woods Can Conceal a Fugitive. But for How Long?
description: Someone on the run can take advantage of natural cover to elude a manhunt for awhile, but experts say technology and time will eventually tip the scales toward the pursuers.
content: After gunning down 18 people and wounding 13 more in Lewiston, Maine, on Wednesday night, the man who carried out the rampage apparently fled the small city, disappearing into a forested region that may — for now — help keep him a step ahead of the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian and Catie Edmondson
title: Ukraine Aid in Doubt as Johnson Moves to Drop It From Israel Assistance Bill
description: The newly elected House speaker, who has opposed continued funding for Kyiv, is now insisting on separating it from aid to Israel, leaving its fate uncertain.
content: Representative Mike Johnson’s election as speaker has thrown the fate of U.S. assistance for Ukraine into doubt, as the Louisiana Republican, a longtime opponent of funding the war effort, resists President Biden’s call to package money for Kyiv in a large emergency spending bill to tackle global crises including Israel’s war against Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Weekender
description: Lionel Messi’s fabulously popular pink jersey. Also: Taylor Swift fan fiction and a new podcast from Serial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Friday Briefing
description: Pressure builds for a pause in Gaza.
content: The leaders of the 27 E.U. nations called yesterday for a break in the fighting in Gaza to address a dire humanitarian crisis inside the territory. Their statement came hours after the Israeli military said it had briefly sent tanks into Gaza in preparation for the next stage of fighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Representative Jared Golden of Maine calls for a ban on assault weapons, reversing a long-held stance.
description: That position, he said, reflected in part “a false confidence that our community was above this, and that we could be in full control, among many other misjudgments.”
content: Representative Jared Golden of Maine, a centrist Democrat, called for a ban on assault weapons Thursday afternoon, reversing a long-held stance after 18 people were killed in a mass shooting in Lewiston.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell and Rowan Niemisto
title: The People v. Meta, Marques Brownlee on YouTube and Future Tech, and DALL-E 3 Arrives
description: Dozens of states sue Meta, we get advice from a pro YouTuber and we examine impressive advancements in artificial intelligence image generators.
content: Dozens of state attorneys general have sued Meta, claiming the company knowingly created features that induce “extended, addictive and compulsive social media use” among teenagers and children. In a country without wide-reaching internet regulations, are lawsuits the way to reign in tech companies?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Arepas, Cornell Chicken and Fresh and Wild Mushroom Stew
description: Some griddling, roasting and easy simmering for your weekend.
content: Good morning. You make corn muffins with corn meal, which is dried ground corn. I like those split and griddled in butter. You make tortillas and pupusas with masa harina, which is corn that’s been cooked and steeped in an alkaline solution (a process known as nixtamalization), then dried and ground. A homemade tortilla is a revelation; a pupusa stuffed with cheese and grated yellow squash is paradise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: They Fled City Jobs. Now, It’s Time for Farm Prom.
description: A group of young urbanites gave up desk jobs to become farmers. They have earned the harvest party.
content: Prom season it was not. A blustery fall wind whipped through the rows of radicchio, across the butternut vines and edged the dance floor. And this was no high school-gym full of awkward teenagers; rather, it was a barn full of farmers. Dressed in their flannel and their finest, they danced into the night at a shindig called Farm Prom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Remy Tumin
title: Did A.I. Write Product Reviews? Gannett Says No.
description: Writers and editors at Reviewed, a product recommendation website, say that the company used artificial intelligence to create reviews last week.
content: When several articles were published last week on Reviewed, a USA Today-owned website that recommends products, something seemed off. No one at Reviewed recognized the bylines on the pieces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Houman Barekat
title: ‘Boy Parts’ Review: Onstage, a Dangerous Woman Isn’t Enough
description: A London production adapted from Eliza Clark’s debut novel refuses to justify its unreliable narrator’s violence, but lacks narrative depth and complexity.
content: How far can you go in the name of art? For Irina, nothing is off-limits. She’s a photographer who takes pictures of young men, with a particular preference for guys that are unprepossessing, shy and biddable. Irina’s “thing” is capturing male vulnerability, so she photographs her subjects in compromising poses; she takes liberties with consent, and violates their dignity in increasingly troubling and violent ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Series Finale Recap: The Last Battle
description: In its final hour, “Billions” delivered that rarest of prestige-TV commodities: a happy ending.
content: Am I at a loss for words over the series finale of “Billions”? That depends. Do hooting and hollering count as “words”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou and Raja Abdulrahim
title: Gaza Goes Dark as Israel Attacks Intensify
description: Two major Palestinian mobile networks, Jawwal and Paltel, said that their phone lines and internet services were down.
content: It was increasingly difficult to reach people in the Gaza Strip or know what was happening in the enclave late Friday, as Israel said it was stepping up its bombardment and staging another incursion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: Night Out in Lewiston Turns Deadly for a Group of Deaf Friends
description: One victim was widely recognized as a sign language interpreter for state briefings during the coronavirus pandemic.
content: Josh Seal and Bryan MacFarlane reveled in their Wednesday night outings at Schemengees Bar and Grille in Lewiston, playing on a cornhole team that was all their own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell, Amelia Nierenberg, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Michael Levenson
title: ‘Dark Day for Maine’ After Gunman Kills 18 at Bowling Alley and Bar
description: Businesses, schools and offices in the southern part of the state were closed on Thursday as the authorities sought a 40-year-old suspect.
content: The familiar rituals of a Wednesday night were playing out at Just-In-Time Recreation, a bowling alley in Lewiston, Maine, with 22 lanes of tenpin and a restaurant serving nachos and wings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Mike Johnson Is a Right-Wing Fever Dream Come to Life
description: There’s a reason Trump likes this guy.
content: Last week, on the eve of his first attempt to become speaker of the House, allies of Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio confidently predicted that his more mainstream and institutionalist opponents would cave rather than resist his ascent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Taylor Swift’s ‘“Slut!”’ and the Evolution of a Pop Star Feminist
description: The bonus track from “1989 (Taylor’s Version)” revisits a moment when she was carefully calibrating her public transition into adulthood and superstardom.
content: A few weeks ago, when Taylor Swift revealed the names of the “From the Vault” bonus tracks that would appear on the rereleased “Taylor’s Version” of her blockbuster 2014 album “1989,” one title stood out, encased in quotations and emphasized with an exclamation mark: “‘Slut!’”
source.name: The New York Times

title: It’s Engagement Season — Here’s What to Get Your Soon-to-Be-Married Friends
description: Timeless décor advice, a Japanese good-luck charm — and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: The intaglio — a stone engraved with an image — is a form of jewelry that goes back to ancient Mesopotamia. “In the Greek and Roman galleries at the Met, there’s a study room that’s full of intaglios,” says the New York-based jewelry designer Jean Prounis. For just over a year, her namesake brand, which often references ancient decorative arts, has been creating personalized intaglios in lapis, carnelian, onyx, jade or gold that can be set as rings or spinning pendants. Once you’ve chosen which of the settings and stones to offer your giftee, Prounis will, she says, ask you or the betrothed a series of questions about the couple’s relationship before suggesting a design, which is then etched on the stone by a specialized intaglio carver. Or she’ll present a menu of options — among them, palm trees, clasped hands and olive branches. Prounis’s designs have also included pet portraits, initials and dates. “It’s kind of like an anthropological study of what modern-day people want to inscribe in stone,” she says. And for the newly engaged, an intaglio can also function as a wax seal: perfect for sending off invitations and thank-you notes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Saffitz
title: This Is the Ultimate Chocolate Cake
description: Claire Saffitz has cracked the code to an irresistible moist-tender cake that’s not too sweet and not too dense.
content: I once read an interview with the French chef Alain Ducasse, in which he said: “Sugar is the enemy of chocolate.” Mr. Ducasse owns his own chocolate company, which makes extraordinary bars and truffles, so I’d be inclined to take his word for it, even if all of my experience as a baker didn’t back up his statement. Undoubtedly, excessive sugar dulls and masks chocolate’s singular flavor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: How Automation Has Changed Work for Casino Employees in Detroit
description: For cocktail servers and hotel housekeepers, the arrival of robotic technologies has made their jobs harder, they say. It’s part of why they’re on strike.
content: On a chilly Wednesday evening in October, the sounds filling Ambre Romero’s home were familiar: her grandchildren unloading the dishwasher, her husband, just off work, watching television. Ms. Romero was getting ready for her shift serving cocktails at the MGM Grand Detroit, the casino where she has worked since 1999. She pulled on her blue bustier top, said goodbye to her family and drove to a nearby gas station to pick up Red Bull and Lucky 13 scratch-off tickets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: BuzzFeed in Advanced Talks to Sell Complex, Backtracking on Digital Media Bet
description: BuzzFeed is negotiating a sale of much of Complex Networks for under $140 million, less than half of what it paid to acquire it two years ago.
content: BuzzFeed is in advanced talks to sell Complex Networks, the streetwise digital media company behind the popular ComplexCon cultural festival, at less than half the price it paid for the company two years ago, a sign of the industrywide troubles afflicting digital media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
title: Does Society Really Need More Elon Musks?
description: Only if billionaire tech bros stay in their lanes.
content: Will technology — and the people who make it — lead us into a better future? Or a worse one? This week on “Matter of Opinion,” the hosts discuss Elon Musk, techno-optimism and the manifesto taking Silicon Valley by storm. Plus, we learn that Ross wears dad drag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: 9 Takeaways From Mike Johnson’s First Interview as Speaker
description: The Louisiana Republican spoke about how his worldview is dictated by the Bible, and discussed issues including abortion, gay marriage and aid for Ukraine.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson said on Thursday evening that his personal worldview and policy positions are dictated by the Bible, in his first extended interview since assuming the job second in line to the presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: Wegman Is Selling His Chelsea Home and Studio, Asking $16.5 Million
description: The artist and his wife are taking Flo, their last Weimaraner, and moving permanently to the country house and studio they own in Ghent, N.Y.
content: For the last three decades, the artist William Wegman has kept his main studio at 245 West 18th Street, a two-story, double-wide building in Chelsea. He painted on the top floor, and on the bottom, shot many of the well-known photographs and videos of his beloved Weimaraners in quirky costumes and poses.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Who Is Troye Sivan Now?
description: A conversation about the pop star’s evolution on his new album, “Something to Give Each Other,” and the ceilings he may still face as an openly gay male performer.
content: The pop singer Troye Sivan released “Something to Give Each Other,” his third album — and first in five years — earlier this month to largely positive reviews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aida Alami
title: A Scientist’s Salons in Paris Cater to a Neglected Trait: Curly Hair
description: With a Ph.D. in chemistry and inspired by her daughter, Aude Livoreil-Djampou is trying to address the dearth of salon options in France for people with coiled or curly hair.
content: When it came time to find a salon for her daughter with coiled hair, Aude Livoreil-Djampou discovered what many women with curly or textured hair in Paris already knew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Olivia Natt, Eric Krupke, Clare Toeniskoetter, Lynsea Garrison, Devon Taylor, Liz O. Baylen, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Pat McCusker and Chris Wood
title: A New Threat: Surprise Hurricanes
description: Hurricane Otis transformed from a tropical storm to a deadly Category 5 hurricane in a day, defying forecasts.
content: Hurricane Otis, which killed more than two dozen people in southern Mexico this week, exemplified a phenomenon that meteorologists fear will become more and more common: a severe hurricane that arrives with little warning or time to prepare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko
title: Their Sons Went Missing Fighting for Ukraine. They Want Answers.
description: In a rare show of public criticism in wartime, families of missing Ukrainian soldiers are pressing the government for information on their status.
content: Hundreds of women draped in Ukrainian flags, carrying banners and balloons, chanted on the street around the corner from the president’s office last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: ‘Covenant’ Review: When Inner Turmoil Is Its Own Ghost Story
description: The playwright York Walker makes a promising New York debut at Roundabout Underground.
content: Much is made over whether one is “with God” or not in “Covenant,” a striking new Southern gothic work by York Walker. Following a town’s reaction to a bluesman’s mysterious homecoming in 1930s Georgia, this small, potent Roundabout Underground production sustains a scorching end-of-days tune as much through its electric cast and design elements as by Walker’s script and Tiffany Nichole Greene’s swift direction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Twohey
title: Inside Kanye West’s Fraught Relationship With Adidas: 7 Takeaways
description: The runaway success of the Yeezy collaboration between Kanye West and Adidas came at a price as the company tolerated misconduct by him for nearly a decade.
content: When Adidas cut ties with Kanye West a year ago, ending their wildly lucrative shoe deal, the breakup appeared to be the culmination of weeks of his inflammatory remarks about Jews and Black Lives Matter. But a New York Times examination found that behind the scenes, the partnership was fraught from the start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Why This Craftsman Can’t Wait for Halloween to Be Over
description: The pressure is on for a professional pumpkin carver, who doesn’t even have time to go trick-or-treating with his children.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday, and it’s almost Halloween. We’ll meet someone who is too busy carving pumpkins to go trick-or-treating with his kids. We’ll also find out why the famous Flatiron Building is becoming something it has never been — a place to live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Dean Phillips’s Last-Minute, Long-Shot Quest to Force Democrats to Reconsider Biden
description: The Minnesota congressman made his presidential bid official in New Hampshire before a crowd of a few dozen people composed largely of journalists and campaign staff.
content: On the last possible day to do so, Representative Dean Phillips of Minnesota walked into the New Hampshire Statehouse on Friday through a side door and submitted paperwork to put his name on the state’s primary ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: How Are You Preparing for a Summer of Fires?
description: As El Niño arrives, heralding dry weather, it feels like the whole country is on edge. We’d like to hear from readers in Australia.
content: Australia is fast heading into our worst fire season since the summer of 2019-2020, or Black Summer, when nearly 500 people died. All-too-familiar images of horrific blazes and blood-red skies are already starting to fill the news. This week, dozens of homes were destroyed and hundreds of people have been evacuated as firefighters battle a wildfire in the Tara region in Queensland. Two people died in two separate fires in New South Wales earlier this month, one of them a firefighter who suffered a medical emergency while on the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: New York City Was the Real Star of ‘Billions’
description: As the Showtime series airs its final episode, the showrunners look back at the essential role the city’s restaurants and neighborhoods played.
content: New York City has been the backdrop for many TV series over the years, from “Law & Order” to “Sex and the City” to “Succession.” But the Showtime series “Billions,” which ends on Sunday after seven seasons, may have been the New Yorkiest of them all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Artists Call for Boycott After Artforum Fires Its Top Editor
description: Several artists have said they will stop working with the magazine after its response to an open letter that called for Palestinian liberation and a cease-fire.
content: One day after Artforum magazine fired its top editor, David Velasco, because of an open letter it published about the Israel-Hamas war, another editor resigned and several prominent artists said they would boycott the publication unless Velasco was reinstated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: What Happened to the American Dream?
description: A new book reckons with decades of disappointment.
content: In the agonized debates over how it can possibly be that Donald Trump has such a strong chance of being returned to the White House in 2024, it’s important to stress the ways in which the Trump economy, before the arrival of Covid, departed in positive ways from the trends of the last half-century. Trump’s presidency was a period not just of steady growth and low unemployment, but also of growth that was more widely shared than in much of the recent past — with the strongest improvement in median incomes since the 1990s, wage growth for middle- and low-income workers outpacing growth for the upper class, and the lowest African American unemployment rate in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: How Elon Musk Changed the Meaning of Twitter for Users
description: Twitter was a deeply personal source of conversation, news and community for many people. One year after Mr. Musk took over, users say that has shifted — for better and for worse.
content: After Nicholas Campiz evacuated from Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, in February 2022, he stayed glued to Twitter. As battles raged across the country, he tracked them on the app, staying up through many nights in a hotel room in Tbilisi, Georgia, to read updates as they rolled in, one tweet at a time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Toyota Recalls More Than 800,000 Highlanders for a Bumper Fix
description: The company said it was recalling the vehicles in North America because of concerns that bumper cover parts could fall off and create hazards on the road.
content: Toyota, the world’s largest automaker, is recalling about 814,000 Highlanders in North America because of concerns that the vehicles’ bumper covers could fall off and create hazards on the road, the company said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: The Start of Maine’s Rifle Hunting Season Could Be Postponed
description: The presence of hunters and the sound of gunfire could disrupt the search for the suspect in the Lewiston shootings.
content: Rifle hunting season for deer is scheduled to begin on Saturday for residents in Maine, posing another challenge for hundreds of law enforcement officers who are searching the state’s wooded areas for the suspect in the Lewiston shootings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Maine Residents Are Warned to Expect a Long, Disruptive Search
description: Patrol cars, helicopters and tactical teams swarmed Friday on any reports that might indicate the presence of the Lewiston gunman.
content: Law enforcement officers rushed from place to place across southern Maine on Friday, their patrol cars and helicopters swarming on any reports that might indicate the presence of Robert R. Card Jr., the suspect in the mass shooting that killed 18 people in Lewiston.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Alessandra Ferri’s Next Act: Running the Vienna State Ballet
description: Ferri, the star ballerina who was a principal at American Ballet Theater, will run the large Vienna company and its affiliated school.
content: The ballerina Alessandra Ferri has had many dance lives. Now she will have another, offstage. On Tuesday, the Vienna State Ballet announced that Ferri, a former principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, would be its next artistic director, succeeding Martin Schläpfer when his contract ends in August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia’s Central Bank Raises Rates to 15 Percent to Curb Inflation
description: The jump, from 13 percent, would bring a long period of “tight monetary conditions” in order to ease price pressures, the bank said.
content: Russia’s Central Bank on Friday raised its key interest rate by two percentage points to 15 percent, a bigger increase than expected as the bank said it was trying to bring down stubbornly high inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 15 Great Songs From 1989 (the Year, Not the Album)
description: A playlist celebrating a staggeringly great year in music: Pixies, Janet Jackson, De La Soul, Madonna, Indigo Girls and more.
content: Today’s playlist is a homage to the music of 1989. Yes, the year. Why, you ask? Does it have anything to do with … you know … a certain musician rereleasing one of her most popular albums, with a title referencing the year she was born? I have no idea what you’re talking about. I simply wanted to celebrate a staggeringly great year in music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Stereo Speaker Battles Blare Celine Dion Tunes and Torment a New Zealand City
description: A subculture has developed among Pacific Islander communities based on who can blast music — often Ms. Dion’s songs — the loudest. Some call it too disruptive.
content: Imagine it’s the middle of the night and you’re jolted awake by the crescendo of a Celine Dion song that is blasting out of loudspeakers affixed to moving cars or bicycles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Students on the Run, Schools Taken by Troops and a Generation’s Catastrophe
description: With an estimated 19 million children out of school for months because of war, Sudan is on the verge of becoming “the worst education crisis in the world,” U.N. officials say.
content: The young girls and boys, wearing colorful scarves, tattered shirts and flip-flops, ran across the dusty ground to form jagged lines and face the teachers at the start of the school day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun and Chang W. Lee
title: Haunted by Guilt, Vilified Online: A Year After the Seoul Crowd Crush
description: Survivors of the Itaewon disaster and relatives of victims continue to wrestle with unanswered questions and grief as they push for official accountability.
content: Over Halloween weekend last year, nearly 160 young people died in a crowd crush in Itaewon, a popular nightlife district in Seoul. For those who survived or lost loved ones, the past year has been a time of deep frustration and trauma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kodé
title: This Community Welcomes Mediums, but First You Have to Prove Yourself
description: A lawsuit against the nonprofit that runs Lily Dale, a New York haven for Spiritualists, has put a spotlight on the hamlet where residents believe death does not exist.
content: Everybody dies. But not in Lily Dale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: (La)Horde: Dancing Out Primal Impulses and Resistance
description: In two programs, (La)Horde and the Ballet National de Marseille introduced New York to work that taps into a youthful, rebellious spirit.
content: The party was already going when people entered the theater for Rone and (La)Horde’s “Room With a View” at N.Y.U. Skirball on Saturday night. A heavy beat pounded, and haze hung in the air around a set of huge, crumbling stone steps. In the middle of this hulking structure, the electronic music artist Rone was playing a D.J. set, surrounded by dancers of Ballet National de Marseille. Below, two performers negotiated a private conflict, erotic and aggressive. Euphoria and danger mingled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Cocktails and ‘Chala-ween’: Readers Share Their Offbeat Rituals
description: We asked you for the everyday acts that add richness to your lives. Here are some of our favorites.
content: Last week, I wrote about the benefits of small rituals, those everyday acts, repeated regularly in a specific way, that add richness and meaning to our lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: The Proxy Forces Iran Has Assembled Across the Middle East
description: A “Shiite Crescent” stretches from Yemen on the Arabian Peninsula through Iraq, Syria and Lebanon and back down to the Gaza Strip.
content: For decades, the Shiite Muslim ayatollahs who came to power in Iran through the 1979 Islamic Revolution have worked to build an arc of like-minded proxy forces across the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: What Is John Eliot Gardiner’s Musical Empire Without Him?
description: The conductor is taking a break after being accused of striking a singer. But the groups he founded continue to tour with a substitute at the podium.
content: To conduct Bach’s Mass in B minor, the conductor John Eliot Gardiner wrote, “is to be filled with a tremendous sense of anticipation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Yankee Fans Can Buy Mickey Mantle’s Childhood Home. The Price: $7.
description: For its first foray into real estate, a collectibles company is offering ownership shares of the Hall of Famer’s Oklahoma house.
content: Long before he was switch-hitting for the New York Yankees, a young Mickey Mantle was taking swings against his right-handed father and his left-handed grandfather in front of a shed next to his family’s humble 670-square-foot house in tiny Commerce, Okla. More often than not, the young slugger would knock the pitches clear over the house’s roof. Sometimes he’d smack line drives into the side of the rusted shed, where visible dings in the walls remain to this day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly, Vivian Nereim, Mark Mazzetti and Edward Wong
title: Saudi Arabia Warns U.S.: Israeli Invasion of Gaza Could Be Catastrophic
description: In discussions with their American counterparts, Saudi officials have framed a ground war as a potentially devastating blow to stability in the Middle East.
content: Saudi officials have firmly warned the United States in recent days that an Israeli ground incursion into Gaza could be catastrophic for the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: How Hard Is It to Wake Up in the Morning?
description: Do you want to smash your alarm each morning? Do you keep hitting snooze? Or do you jump up to meet each day?
content: The alarm rings. Do you hide your head under the pillow and try your best to block out the blaring noise? Do you hit the snooze button over and over and drift back to sleep, if only for a few more minutes? Or do you jump out of bed, eager to greet the new day?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: A Hairless Cat and Nickelback. What Could Be More Romantic?
description: When performers Kayla Pecchioni and Colin Barkell met at a Tonys viewing party, a kitten named Paw McCatney helped break the ice.
content: On Sept. 26, 2021, Colin Ernest Barkell spotted Kayla Dianne Pecchioni stroking her hairless kitten at a screening of the Tony Awards. He was instantly attracted. Especially to the cat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Moity
title: Want to Marvel at Next Year’s Total Solar Eclipse? Book Now.
description: Hotels are already selling out in places that will see total darkness on April 8, and prices are soaring where rooms are still available.
content: In just over five months, a total solar eclipse will blot out the sun across a wide swath of North America for the first time since 2017. If you want to catch a seat at the show, you might want to book your room now — and be prepared to pay a premium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Twohey
title: Investigating Kanye
description: How Adidas looked past misconduct in its partnership with Ye, the rapper formerly known as Kanye West.
content: When Adidas ended its wildly lucrative shoe deal with Kanye West, who now goes by Ye, a year ago, the breakup appeared to be the culmination of weeks of his inflammatory remarks about Jews and Black Lives Matter. But our examination found that behind the scenes, the partnership was fraught from the start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Artforum Fires Top Editor After Its Open Letter on Israel-Hamas War
description: David Velasco was removed after the magazine’s publishers said there was a flawed editorial process behind the publication of a letter that supported Palestinian liberation.
content: One of the art world’s top magazine editors was fired Thursday night after the publishers of Artforum said that the staff’s decision to post an open letter about the Israel-Hamas war failed to meet the organization’s standards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: An Unexpectedly Relevant Oratorio at the Philharmonic
description: Planned over a year ago, Handel’s “Israel in Egypt” was presented while the Israel-Hamas war unfolds in the Middle East.
content: Handel is not a composer typically associated with controversy, but the New York Philharmonic found itself entering a difficult public discourse with its performances of the oratorio “Israel in Egypt” this week at David Geffen Hall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Ivor Robson, Golf’s Celebrated Voice at British Open, Dies at 83
description: For four decades he announced the names of players — Jack Nicklaus, Tiger Woods, Rory McIlroy and more — before they teed off. He rarely took a break.
content: At the British Open, a Scotsman named Ivor Robson became one of the most distinctive and revered voices in golf by saying little. Called a starter, he stood at a lectern near the first tee at each round of that major championship, where his job was simple: to introduce each player.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: Man-grasshopper hybrids, not-quite space travel and very brief time travel in this month’s collection of sci-fi picks.
content: Hideaki Anno is everywhere these days. In addition to leading a multi-feature “rebuild” of his anime series “Neon Genesis Evangelion,” he has been writing the recent reboots, including “Shin Ultraman,” of Japanese pop-entertainment figures. The latest of those movies, which Anno also directed, centers on Hongo (Sosuke Ikematsu), a hybrid of man and grasshopper who rides a motorbike. With the help of his creator’s daughter, Ruriko (Minami Hamabe), Hongo battles a series of similarly “augmented” hybrids — think Bat-Aug (Toru Tezuka), Wasp-Aug (Nanase Nishino) and so on — who fight on behalf of a fascist organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: This Turkey Just Will Not Stop Crossing the Road
description: In West Orange, N.J., the morning commute is complicated by a fearless wild turkey who regularly runs into traffic.
content: A wild turkey stood on a grassy knoll in suburban New Jersey, a tranquilizer dart protruding like a blue and orange battle scar from its chest. Suddenly the bird spotted a jogger and charged, racing headlong into traffic. Motorists swerved and stopped. Finally, a driver came to the rescue, jumping out of his car and racing onto the knoll, baiting the turkey to give chase. The bird was soon back on his perch, and the Friday morning commute resumed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Martin and Francesca Scorsese, TikTok’s Dynamic Duo
description: The acclaimed director’s daughter, a filmmaker herself, has been peppering her feed with videos of her father, showing a rarely seen side of him.
content: Step aside, Leonardo DiCaprio. Martin Scorsese seems to have found a new muse: Oscar, his daughter Francesca Scorsese’s aptly named miniature schnauzer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Carlos Lozada Interviews McKay Coppins
description: The Oct. 27, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Carlos Lozada, with McKay Coppins. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Calls Out Mike Johnson’s First Fail
description: The “Late Show” host chided the new House speaker for offering little more than thoughts and prayers to survivors of the Maine shooting on his first day in office.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Why Has This 258-Year-Old Mansion Been Left to Fall Apart?
description: The historic Morris-Jumel Mansion is the “crown jewel of Sugar Hill” in Manhattan — and a victim of bureaucratic and financial neglect.
content: The Morris-Jumel Mansion, designed in the neo-Palladian style, is the oldest surviving house in Manhattan, an irreplaceable artifact described by Duke Ellington as “the crown jewel of Sugar Hill,” one of the places where Lin-Manuel Miranda composed songs for “Hamilton.” In its current life, it supplies a strange and unwelcome souvenir — pieces of itself. The building has been so badly maintained that it is possible to touch it and walk away with a moist, splintered clump of wood siding in the palm of your hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Caldwell
title: What’s Happening in Germany Reveals the Strange State of the Left
description: Sahra Wagenknecht’s new political party threatens to be transformative.
content: On Monday morning, Sahra Wagenknecht, the most charismatic politician in Germany’s Left party, led an uprising against it. A longtime member of the national Parliament and until 2019 a co-leader of the Left’s parliamentary delegation, Ms. Wagenknecht apparently now has a different idea of what “left” means. She announced that she and nine fellow Parliament members will start a new party in January to court voters who share her discontent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Murder Suspect Who Escaped From Police at D.C. Hospital Is Recaptured
description: Christopher Haynes was taken to George Washington University Hospital, on Sept. 6 after he complained of an injury. He assaulted an officer and fled, the police said.
content: The authorities on Thursday recaptured a murder suspect who the police say escaped from a Washington, D.C., hospital nearly two months ago by assaulting an officer and fleeing, with a handcuff dangling from one arm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Dowling
title: A Stroke of Serendipity, a Stunning Solar Eclipse
description: Danielle Dowling, an editor for The New York Times, recently traveled to Texas Hill Country to witness the event in person.
content: Throughout my life, I’ve wondered: Why is the universe the way it is?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
title: The Good. The Bad. The Ugly. Inside Berlusconi’s Art Collection.
description: The Italian media mogul bought up some 25,000 paintings, many on TV shopping binges, before he died this year. Now no one knows what to do with them.
content: As his political fortunes sank, his legal and love life tangled, and his age caught up with him, Silvio Berlusconi stayed up late in his mansion outside Milan calling the hotlines of late-night art shopping television channels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Guerrero
title: ‘Franning It Up’ at New York’s Most No-Nonsense Party
description: Blazers, jeans and candy cigarettes were the dress code at FranCon, an event dedicated to the writer Fran Lebowitz.
content: At a party on Thursday night in an East Village bar, Jane Ashe, 71, paired denim pants with a white collared shirt and a blazer. “It’s one party I knew what to wear,” Ms. Ashe said. Heather Frankel, 51, followed a similar formula, but added sunglasses and a top she bought from a thrift store specifically for the event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Strikes Iranian-Linked Targets in Syria
description: The Pentagon said the airstrikes against facilities used by the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps and its proxies were in retaliation for recent rocket and drone attacks on American forces.

content: The Adidas team was huddled with Kanye West, pitching ideas for the first shoe they would create together. The Adidas employees, thrilled to get started, had arrayed sneakers and fabric swatches on a long table near a mood board pinned with images.

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: Daniel Raymon’s latest puzzle puts us through our cryptic paces.
content: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — Daniel Raymon is one of a handful of constructors who make cryptic crosswords, puns and anagrams, and daily grids for The New York Times. Each type of puzzle has its own rules and a different reputation for its difficulty. This variety puzzle, which is nicknamed the “PandA,” borrows wordplay-filled clues from the cryptic — a glossary is invaluable, until you’ve learned the styles by heart — and grid geometry from the regular crossword, which means that every square has two entries running through it. Those traits combine to make a merry jumble of tricks that should all be solvable because of those crossing letters, as well as the presence of anagrams. A flexible mind also helps a great deal.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Yoko Ono and the Women of Fluxus Changed the Rules in Art and Life
description: A show at the Japan Society focuses on four innovators who created a blueprint for a new society with postcards, scissors, chess sets and instructions.
content: Squatting over a large paper surface with a paintbrush dangling between her legs. Sitting onstage at Carnegie Hall while audience members come up to snip her clothing off with scissors. Blowing soap bubbles to make musical sounds. These are some of the actions taken in the name of art in “Out of Bounds: Japanese Women Artists in Fluxus” at the Japan Society, an exhibition that focuses on four revolutionary women, Shigeko Kubota, Takako Saito, Mieko Shiomi, and one you’ve probably heard of before, Yoko Ono.

content: Joe Hill, a purveyor of maritime junk and jewels and a swashbuckling South Street Seaport fixture for decades, died on Oct. 17 in Huntington, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 76.

title: Is the Republican Speakership Cursed? Johnson Is About to Find Out.
description: Kevin McCarthy was just the latest in a series of Republican speakers and speaker wannabes who faced revolts. Speaker Mike Johnson should take note.
content: Republicans didn’t have a speaker for 40 years until Newt Gingrich finally reclaimed the gavel for the party in 1995 after decades in the wilderness. But hanging on to it has proved extremely challenging for Republicans in the years since — a potential object lesson for incoming Speaker Mike Johnson.

title: ‘I Feel a Human Deterioration’
description: The Israeli writer Etgar Keret has spent the last few weeks trying to make sense of the violence and loss around him. So far, he can’t.
content: When I spoke with the writer Etgar Keret at home in Tel Aviv earlier this week, he was in anguish. Keret is one of Israel’s most beloved contemporary authors, whose books include “Suddenly, a Knock on the Door” and “The Seven Good Years.” He primarily writes short stories that are whimsical, surrealist and darkly funny, and that make meaning from life’s smallest, most unremarkable interactions.

content: Imagine if Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the crypto trading firm FTX and defendant in one of the largest financial fraud trials in history, was actually named Samson, rather than Samuel. Like the biblical character, Mr. Bankman-Fried’s symbolic shearing for his courtroom appearance may become a fabled reflection of promise brought low in the tales to come of our digital age.

title: Scary Stories to Ruin Your Sleep
description: With Halloween around the corner, Gilbert Cruz talks to the Book Review editors Tina Jordan and Sadie Stein about their favorite creepy books.
content: You don’t need Halloween to justify reading scary books, any more than you need sand to justify reading a beach novel. But the holiday does give editors here a handy excuse to talk about some of their favorite spooky reads. On this week’s episode, the host Gilbert Cruz talks with his colleagues Tina Jordan and Sadie Stein about the enduring appeal of ghost stories, Gothic novels and the horror genre as a whole.

title: The Conflicted Legacy of Mitt Romney
description: McKay Coppins discusses the Republican politician’s soul searching across a decades-long career.
content: After factional infighting dominated the G.O.P.’s struggle to elect a House speaker, it feels weirdly quaint to revisit Mitt Romney’s career. He’s served as a governor, a U.S. senator and a presidential nominee for a Republican Party now nearly unrecognizable from what it was when he started out. At the end of his time in public office, he has found a new clarity in his identity as the consummate institutionalist in an increasingly anti-constitutionalist party. But as a newly published biography of him shows, that wasn’t always the case.

description: Young women let the director know how influential she is. But it’s still a battle to make films like her acclaimed “Priscilla.”
content: Sofia Coppola is so drawn to the idea of becoming that she sometimes finds it hard to grasp that she became. Over eight feature films — including her latest, “Priscilla,” about the young Priscilla Presley’s tumultuous relationship with Elvis — she has delved deeply into the liminal stage that is a young woman’s coming-of-age. So you can hardly blame Coppola that after staying in that head space for so long, it comes as a surprise that 25 years have passed since filming her debut feature, “The Virgin Suicides.”

content: Alice McDermott is rightly celebrated for her granular, nuanced portraits of mid-20th-century life, with a particular focus on Irish Americans. Her fans may be startled, then, to find themselves plunged into 1963 Saigon at the start of her enveloping new novel, “Absolution,” whose lofty title belies its sensory, gritty humanity.

The park’s mountains, forests and meadows are home to the largest concentration of mammals in the lower 48 states, including the native bison and a restored population of gray wolves.
